metadata.title: Foliar application of selenium and nano-selenium affects pomegranate (Punica granatum cv. Malase Saveh) fruit yield and quality

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
South African Journal of Botany
j ourna l homepage: www.e lsev ie r .com/ locate /sa jb
Foliar application of selenium and nano-selenium affects pomegranate (Punica granatum cv. Malase Saveh) fruit yield and quality
Seyed Morteza Zahedi a,⁎, Marjan Sadat Hosseini b, Naghmeh Daneshvar Hakimi Meybodi c, Jaime A. Teixeira da Silva d
a Department of Horticultural Science, Faculty of Agriculture, University of Maragheh, Maragheh, Iran b Department of Horticultural Science, Faculty of Agriculture, University of Hormozgan, Bandar Abbas, Iran c Department of Horticulture, College of Agricultural Science and Engineering, Campus of Agriculture and Natural Resources, University of Tehran, Karaj, Iran d P. O. Box 7, Miki-cho post office, Ikenobe 3011-2, Kagawa-ken 761-0799, Japan
⁎ Corresponding author. E-mail address: S.M.Zahedi@maragheh.ac.ir (S.M. Zah
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.sajb.2019.05.019 0254-6299/© 2019 SAAB. Published by Elsevier B.V. All ri
a b s t r a c t a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 29 November 2018 Received in revised form 21 March 2019 Accepted 11 May 2019 Available online xxxx
Edited by M Vaculik
This study examined the impact of selenium (Se) (added as Na2SeO4) and Se nanoparticles (N-Se), as a foliar spray, on several growth parameters, mineral content of leaves, yield, physical and biochemical characteristics of pomegranate (Punica granatum L. cv. Malase Saveh). The experiment was conducted over two consecutive years in the northwest of Iran. Se and N-Se were applied once in 2016 and once in 2017 at 1 and 2 μM (Se1 and Se2, N-Se1 and N-Se2, respectively), first at the full-bloom stage and then one month later. Control plants were sprayed with Se-free water. N-Se2 significantly increased the following parameters in the first year (2016) and second year (2017), respectively: leaf area (1.22- and 1.25-fold), chlorophyll content (1.34- and 1.24-fold), number of fruits/tree (1.35- and 1.28-fold), peel thickness (1.33- and 1.27-fold), fruit diameter (1.08- and 1.10-fold), and yield (1.17- and 1.16-fold). N-Se2 significantly increased N (1.23- and 1.22-fold), P (1.36- and 1.44-fold), K (1.08- and 1.11-fold), Ca (1.12- and 1.17-fold), Fe (1.15- and 1.18-fold) and Se (3.33- and 3.25-fold) content in leaves in both years while Zn content was higher after N-Se2 (1.03- and 1.07-fold) and Se1 (1.02- and 1.04-fold) treatments in both years. N-Se2 significantly increased, relative to the control and in the first and second year, respectively, total sugars (1.17- and 1.19-fold), the content of phenolic compounds (1.05- and 1.08-fold), antioxidants (1.23- and 1.25-fold), and anthocyanins (1.23- and 1.27-fold). Se and N-Se treatments enhanced maturity index and decreased fruit cracking. Broadly, our results indicate that a high concentration of N-Se has a greater and more beneficial impact than a low concentration. Future experiments should focus on increasing the concentration of N-Se. These findings can assist in pomegranate fruit production in arid regions.
© 2019 SAAB. Published by Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
Keywords: Anthocyanin Biophysical parameters Elements Fruit cracking N-Se Pomegranate

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Pomegranate (Punica granatum L.; Punicaceae) is a fruit-bearing deciduous shrub or small tree that originated from Iran and iswell adapted to a Mediterranean climate, and is thus grown extensively around the globe, but primarily in Spain, India, Egypt, Afghanistan and the USA (Davarpanah et al., 2018). It is a rich source of polyphenols, antioxidants, and organic compounds. Pomegranate is mainly consumed as a fresh fruit, but it is also used in jams, juices, wines, vinegars and jellies (Gumienna et al., 2016). This fruit is widely adapted to a wide range of climates and water conditions and is able to tolerate abiotic stresses (Rodríguez Hernández et al., 2012; Teixeira da Silva et al., 2013; Bugueño et al., 2016). These qualities make pomegranate an attractive candidate fruit crop for culture on marginal lands and thus resource-
edi).
ghts reserved.
poor farming. Pomegranate growth and yield are affected by climate, soil conditions, cultivar, insect management, tree nutrition management, and irrigation (Obaid and Al-Hadethi, 2013). Pomegranate consumption has increased in recent years due to the organoleptic characteristics of its fruit and benefits to human health (Rodríguez Hernández et al., 2012). Essential elements are required for plant growth, reproduction, fertilization, fruit yield and quality (Davarpanah et al., 2016, 2018).
A beneficial element and quasi-essential micronutrient to higher plants is selenium (Se). In plants, Se is needed for antioxidant defense since it induces the expression of sulfur assimilation genes (Djanaguiraman et al., 2010; Hasanuzzaman et al., 2014) and is an integral part of the enzyme glutathione peroxidase (Peng et al., 2007; Hajiboland et al., 2015). Supplementationwith Se can enhance glutathione peroxidase (GPx) and the activity of other Se-based proteins (Oraghi-Ardebili et al., 2015). Se is used to counteract various abiotic stresses, such as salt stress (Djanaguiraman et al., 2005;
Hawrylak-Nowak, 2009), heavy metals (Cartes et al., 2010; MroczekZdyrska andWójcik, 2012), and drought (Yao et al., 2009). It exerts beneficial effects on plant growth and stress tolerance by enhancing their antioxidative capacity (Ríos et al., 2009). Even though several studies has been conducted on the effect of Se on some plants, including positive aspects (Haghighi et al., 2014; Bystrická et al., 2015), it has still not yet clear if Se is an essential element for plants. Despite this, the positive effect of Se at 2–10 μM on growth or yield-related parameters has been shown in orange tree (Ibrahim and Al-Wasfy, 2014), sorghum (Djanaguiraman et al., 2010), tomato (Haghighi et al., 2014; Bystrická et al., 2015) and some other plants (Cartes et al., 2010; Akladious, 2012; Badawy et al., 2017). In several cases, Se enhanced yield- and growth-related characters, but the improvement was dependent on concentration (Djanaguiraman et al., 2010; Haghighi et al., 2014; Ibrahim and Al-Wasfy, 2014). Most agricultural crops have a much lower ability to adapt to Se (b50 mg Se/kg) but some plants with a high sulfur (S) content have a high Se concentration (Puccinelli et al., 2017). Se may prevent oxidative damage by inducing a higher expression of S-assimilation genes (Djanaguiraman et al., 2010) or the production of polyphenols (Bystrická et al., 2015). These studies indicated that several growthparameters, nutritional status of trees, yield andphysical and chemical characteristics of fruits were enhanced by the use of Se. Some crop production areas around theworld are deficient in Se, so different forms of this element have been used, either as a foliar or soil application, or in seed priming, to increase the growth, quality or edible parts of crops (Djanaguiraman et al., 2010; Haghighi et al., 2014; Ibrahim and Al-Wasfy, 2014).
Nanoparticles are atomic or molecular aggregates with a size ranging from 1 to 100 nm than can affect the physicochemical properties of a substance relative to its bulk form (Pérez-de-Luque, 2017). Nanoparticles such as nano-Se (N-Se), which is soluble and highly stable (Sharma et al., 2014), has attracted widespread attention because of its low toxicity and high bioavailability (Abdulsalam et al., 2018). The size of nanoparticles plays an important role in their biological activity, especially in the range of 5–200 nm, so N-Se can scavenge free radicals in a size-dependent manner (Peng et al., 2007). N-Se has excellent bioavailability, high biological activity, and low toxicity in plants (Zhang et al., 2001).
Pomegranate is widely cultivated in semi-arid and arid areas of Iran, where, according to the FAO, cultivation area and total production in 2017 were 900,000 ha and ca. 1,000,000 tons, respectively (FAOSTAT, 2018), accounting for 25% of global pomegranate-related exports (Salehi et al., 2016). Fruit cracking is a major problem in pomegranate fruit production in many agricultural areas in Iran and causes financial losses to growers each year amounting to losses exceeding more than 35% of pomegranate production (Mirzaee et al., 2017). Considering the beneficial effects of Se and N-Se on fruit quantity and quality, in particular their ability to stimulate the production of antioxidants and polyphenols, the purpose of this study was to examine if foliar sprays with Se and N-Se would affect yield, quality, and chemical properties of pomegranate fruit and juice.

sections.heading: 2.1. Experimental site, plant materials and treatments
sections.text:
The experimentwas carried out over two years (2016 and 2017) in a commercial pomegranate orchard where the cultivar “Malase Saveh” was grown. The orchard was located in Nemahil, Ardabil province in north-west Iran (Nemahil village, Khalkhal county; 37°15′21″N, 48°24′31″E, altitude 1270 m). Maximum, average, minimum air temperature and daily precipitation were 28.7, 16.13, −2.3 °C, and 285.2 mm in 2016 and 26.8, 12.89, −4.5 °C, and 241.1 mm in 2017. The soil was sandy-loamy (58% sand, 15% clay and 27% silt) with a pH of 7.8 in water and an electrical conductivity of 8.77 dS/m (Isfahan Agriculture and Natural Resources Research Center, Isfahan, Iran). Trees, which
were 10 years old and approximately 3–3.5m in height, were irrigated by a drip irrigation system. Average irrigation volume of well water was based on crop evapotranspiration (4250.06 L/tree). In winter, NPK fertilizer (as NH4NO3, P2O5 and K2SO4, respectively) was applied as a soil drench at 120:120:120 g/tree.
The foliar application of Se was carried out using sodium selenite (Na2SeO4, Sigma-Aldrich, St. Louis, MO, USA) and N-Se (Iranian Nanomaterials Pioneers Co., Mashhad, Iran) liquid mixture. Se and NSewere sprayed on the upper surface of leaves (until full foliagewetting at about 5 L/tree) at 1 or 2 μM(Se1, Se2, N-Se1, and N-Se2, respectively) because in some plants, these concentrations were most effective (Hasanuzzaman et al., 2010, 2014). Such levels were also cost effective. The properties of N-Se used in this experiment are shown in Table 1. Trees were sprayed twice on April 26th 2016 and April 19th 2017 one week before the first full bloom. Leaves were sampled from the middle part of fruit-bearing branches (a total of 85 leaves were sampled from three branches within each tree canopy) on September 1 in the first year and on August 25 in the second year (approximately 90 days after full bloom) (Davarpanah et al., 2016). Fruits were harvested on November 15 in the first year and on November 9 in the second year, and harvest date was based on general fruit appearance (aril and husk color, size and shape).

sections.heading: 2.2. Measurements
sections.text:
Macro- and micronutrients in developing leaves were measured in both years. Samples were prepared according to Chapman and Pratt (1961). N content was determined using the Kjeldhal method (Eaton et al., 1995). Kwasmeasured by flame photometry (PFP7, Staffordshire, UK). P and Ca were determined by spectrophotometry (Cary 100, Richmond, VA, USA). Fe, Zn and Mn were measured using flame atomic absorption spectrophotometry (Unicam model AA-929, Geleen, the Netherlands). To measure Se content, shoot samples were oven-dried at 60 °C until constant weight, then homogenized. Approximately 0.5 g of each samplewas acid-digestedwith 650ml/L of concentrated ultrapure HNO3 using a single reaction chamber microwave-assisted digestion. Se concentration was then determined by ICP-OES (Mimmo et al., 2017).
To determine the physical properties of fruit, five fruits were randomly selected at the end of each treatment from each tree and fruit weight was measured using an electronic balance. Morphological responses were assessed by recording leaf area (Image J Software, National Institutes of Health, Bethesda, MD, USA), fruit diameter and length (mm) and peel thickness (digital Vernier gauge; Mitutoyo, Kanagawa, Japan) (Tehranifar et al., 2010a). Chlorophyll (chl) content was recorded using exactly the same leaves from the same plants, using a SPAD-502 chl meter (Konica-Minolta, Tokyo, Japan) (Mielke et al., 2010).
The number of fruits affected by any level of cracking on each tree was counted and the results were expressed as a relative percentage of fruits affected by cracking. To determine aril weight of each fruit, fruits were manually peeled and the weight of total arils and weight of 100 arils were measured. The weight of 100 arils was measured and the juice volume of 100 g of arils, extracted by a manual extractor
(HR1366, Philips, Amsterdam, The Netherlands), was expressed in mL/ 100 g arils. For all physical parameters, five replications per treatment and year were assessed.
Total soluble solids (TSS) and pH were measured in juice at room temperature using a digital refractometer (A.PAL-1, ATAGO, Tokyo, Japan) and a digital pH meter (HANNA Instruments; Woonsocket, RI, USA), respectively. Titratable acidity (TA) in juice was determined by a titration method (to pH 8.2 with 0.1 M NaOH) and results were expressed as a percentage of citric acid (AOAC, 1995). The TSS:TA ratio was determined as maturity index (AOAC, 1995). Five replications per treatment and year were carried out.
Total antioxidant activity in juice was assessed using the 2,2- diphenyl-1-picrylhydrazyl (DPPH) assay (Dokhanieh et al., 2013). 100 μL of juice was added to 1.0 mL of 60 μmol/L DPPH (free radical, 95%; Sigma–Aldrich Chemie GmbH, Steinheim, Germany) in methanol. After shaking, the mixture was left at room temperature for 30 min, then absorbance was measured with a spectrophotometer (Cary 100; Richmond, VA, USA) at 515 nm. Methanol was used as the standard.
For phenolic compound analysis, 100 μL of juice was mixed with 400 μL phosphate buffer and 2.5 mL of Folin reagent (Sigma–Aldrich). After 1 min, 2 mL of Na2CO3 (7.5%) was added to the mixture and the sample was kept at 50 °C for 5 min before measuring absorbance at 760 nm with a spectrophotometer (Cary 100). Gallic acid was used as the standard (Mirdehghan and Rahimi, 2016).
Total anthocyanins were estimated by the pH differential method using two buffer systems: 25mMKCl buffer (pH 1.0) and 0.4 MNa acetate buffer (pH 4.5) (Giusti and Wrolstad, 2001). Samples were diluted with KCl buffer until A510 was within a linear range of the spectrophotometer. The same dilution factor was later used to dilute the sample with Na acetate buffer. Readings were performed after incubating for 15 min at 510 and 700 nm in the two buffers, five times per sample, and total anthocyanin content was calculated as indicated by Giusti and Wrolstad (2001):
[(A × MW × DF × 100)/MA].where A = (A510– A700); MW=molecularweight; DF= dilution factor;MA=molar absorptive coefficient of cyanidin-3-glucoside (C3G). Resultswere expressed asmgC3G/100 g of juice.
Total soluble sugar in juice was determined by the anthrone reagent method (Dubois et al., 1951). A certain volume of juicewas dilutedwith distilledwater, and then 0.1 mLof thediluted juicewas added to4 mLof anthrone (150 mg pure anthrone in 100 mL of 72% H2SO4). Samples were heated for 10 min in a boiling water bath, and after cooling to room temperature, A625 was determined using a spectrophotometer. Total soluble sugar content was calculated by using a glucose standard curve.

sections.heading: 2.3. Statistical analysis
sections.text:
The experiment was carried out in a completely randomized block design with five replications per treatment. The data obtained in 2016 and 2017 seasons were subjected to analysis of variance according to Clarke and Kempson (1997). Data were statistically analyzed by oneway ANOVA. Data were analyzed using SAS software version 9.1
(Statistical Analysis System; SAS Institute Inc., Cary, NC, USA). Significant differences between means were assessed by Duncan's multiple range test at P b .05. Principal component analysis (PCA), Pearson's correlation coefficient, and dendrogram clustering were carried out with R v3.4.3 (https://www.r-project.org/).

sections.heading: 3.1. Foliar spray with N-Se and Se: impact on leaf area, chlorophyll content, number of fruits, and yield
sections.text: Relative to the control, Se1, Se2 and N-Se2 significantly enhanced leaf surface in both years, all Se and N-Se treatments significantly increased total chl content and number of fruits/tree in both years, while all Se and N-Se treatments significantly increased yield in the first year but only by Se1, Se2 and N-Se2 in the second year (Table 2). For all of these parameters, the greatest increase was induced by N-Se2.

sections.heading: 3.2. Foliar spray with N-Se and Se: impact on leaf mineral content
sections.text: Relative to the control, all Se and N-Se treatments significantly increased the following parameters: leaf N in the first year, but by Se1, Se2 and N-Se2 in the second year; leaf P by N-Se2 in the first year but by N-Se1 and N-Se2 in the second year; leaf K by N-Se1, N-Se2 and Se1 in both years; leaf Ca by N-Se1 and N-Se2 in both years (Table 3); leaf Fe by N-Se2 and Se2 in the first year but by N-Se2, Se1 and Se2 in the second year; leaf Mn content by N-Se2, Se1 and Se2 in the second year; leaf Zn content by N-Se2 in the first year but by N-Se2 and Se1 in the second year (Table 4). N-Se2 almost consistently caused an increase in the content of all minerals in both years, except for Mn. In both years, Se2 and N-Se1 significantly decreased K and Fe content in leaves. In addition, in both years, N-Se2 significantly increased Se content in leaves (Fig. 1).

sections.heading: 3.3. Foliar spray with N-Se and Se: impact on maturity index, total soluble sugars, total phenolic compounds, antioxidant activity and total anthocyanins
sections.text: Relative to the control, all Se and N-Se treatments significantly increased fruit maturity index in the first year, but by Se1 and Se2 in the second year; all Se and N-Se treatments significantly increased total soluble sugar content in the second year, but by N-Se2, Se1 and Se2 in the first year; all Se and N-Se treatments significantly increased total phenolic content and antioxidant activity in both years; N-Se2, Se1 and Se2 significantly increased total anthocyanin content in both years (Table 5).

sections.heading: 3.4. Foliar spray with N-Se and Se: impact on fruit cracking, peel thickness, weight, length, and diameter
sections.text:
Relative to the control, all Se and N-Se treatments significantly increased peel thickness, fruit weight, fruit length and fruit diameter, and significantly decreased fruit cracking in both years (Table 6). The
um L. cv. Malase Saveh) leaf area, chlorophyll content (SPAD value), number of fruits, and
only exception was N-Se at both concentrations, which significantly reduced fruit weight in the first year.

sections.heading: 3.5. Foliar spray with N-Se and Se: impact on chemical properties
sections.text: Relative to the control, N-Se2 and Se1 significantly increased the weight of 100 arils in the first year, but not in the second year; N-Se2, Se1 and Se2 significantly increased juice content, juice pH and TSS (%) in both years, with only two exceptions, a significant increase in juice pH by N-Se1 in the second year and no significant increase in TSS (%) by Se2 in the first year; N-Se2, Se1 and Se2 significantly decreased TA (%) in the first year but only Se2 in the second year (Table 7).

sections.heading: 3.6. Principal component analysis and dendogram clustering of foliar spray with N-Se and Se-treated
sections.text:
All 26 biomass, physiological, biochemical and yield traits were loaded into twomajor principal components (PC1 and PC2), explaining 89.90 and 91.5% of the total variance in 2016 and 2017, respectively (Fig. 2A). Most of the examined traits were discriminated by PC1, and thus explained by the larger proportion of variance (70.70 and 77.20%)while a lower proportion of variance (19.3 and 14.3%)was indicated by PC2 in both 2016 and 2017, respectively (Fig. 2A). PCA plots separated the treatment groups into five main groups: (i) pomegranate trees grown under control condition (non-spraying), (ii) pomegranate trees treated with 1 and 2 μM Se-nanoparticles, and (iii) pomegranate trees treated with 1 and 2 μM Se (Fig. 2B). All physiological and biochemical traits, except for fruit cracking, were positively associated with N-Se2- and Se1-treated pomegranate trees (Fig. 2A and B), while fruit cracking was positively linked with control and N-Se1-treated pomegranate trees (Fig. 2A and B).
Pearson's correlation analysis demonstrated that yield was positively correlated with yield-related traits (fruit weight and fruit diameter) (Fig. 3A). In contrast, fruit cracking displayed a negative correlation with leaf area, total chl, number of fruits, N, P, K, Ca, Fe, Mn and Zn content, and peel thickness (Fig. 3A). Furthermore, cluster analysis separated pomegranate trees based on different Se-NP and Se treatments (Fig. 3B), dividing them into tree clades, as shown by a dendrogram (Fig. 3B). Clade I contained control pomegranate trees (2016 and 2017), whereas clade II harbored pomegranate trees treated with 1 and 2 μM Se (2016 and 2017), as well as trees grown under N-Se1 and 2 (2017) application. Clade III contained N-Se1 and 2 (2016) (Fig. 3B).

sections.heading: 4.1. Effect of nano-selenium and selenium foliar spray on chlorophyll content, and yield
sections.text:
Our study indicates that Se and N-Se had, overall, several significantly positive effects on morphological, vegetative, and organoleptic properties and yield in pomegranate, and although trendswere not consistent for both years, the most significant effect was by N-Se2.
Ragavan et al. (2017) found that 300 and 400 mg/L N-Se significantly enhanced the leaf area of cluster bean (Cyamopsis tetragonoloba
(while Ibrahim and Al-Wasfy (2014) found that the application of 50 mg/L Se enhanced leaf area in orange trees (Citrus sinensis cv. Valencia). Some researchers did not observe any positive effect of Se on chl content in plants such as potato (Solanum tuberosum) (Germ et al., 2007) and sorghum (Sorghum bicolor) (Djanaguiraman et al., 2010). In contrast, chl content was significantly increased in potato when Se was applied at 10 mg/L (Germ et al., 2007), 50 mg/L in soybean (Glycine max) (Djanaguiraman et al., 2005), 5 μM in tomato (Solanum lycopersicum) (Haghighi et al., 2014), 50 mg/L in citrus (Ibrahim and Al-Wasfy, 2014), and 10 μM in potato (Ibrahim and Ibrahim, 2016), or by the application of 1 μMN-Se in tomato (Haghighi et al., 2014) or 400 mg/L in cluster bean (Ragavan et al., 2017). These different results may be due to differences in crop species, experimental conditions, or the plants' ability to biofortify Se (Haghighi et al., 2014). Hu et al. (2018) noted that nanoparticle size andmethod of synthesis of N-Se affected their uptake rate by plants, with N-Se nanoparticles smaller than 50 nm in diameter were more easily absorbed. Thus, the use of small diameter NSe with optimized water management may improve the absorption of N-Se by plants in the field, serving as a new fertilizer to produce Sebiofortified plants in a bid to improve Se supplementation in humans and domestic animals.
The optimal concentration of Se may play an important role in increasing leaf pigments by enhancing the capacity of antioxidants and delaying the senescence of leaf tissues while an increase in chl content may be attributed to the ability of Se to protect chloroplast enzymes, affect the oxidation reduction status of leaves, and thus increase the biosynthesis of photosynthetic pigments (Zhong and Cheng, 2017). Seinduced plant growth was due to an increase in starch accumulation in chloroplasts (Turakainen et al., 2004). Pomegranate yield, expressed as theweight of fruits/tree and fruit-related parameters (length, weight and diameter), improved significantly in response to Se, even more so with N-Se, relative to the control (Tables 2 and 5), as was also found in jujube (Ziziphus jujuba) trees by applying a foliar Se spray (Jing et al., 2017). Yield is related to physiological responses such as photosynthesis that may enhance chl content (Sid'ko et al., 2017). The use of Se also increased yield in citrus (Ibrahim and Ibrahim, 2016), biomass and yield in garlic (Allium sativum) (Põldma et al., 2013; Cheng et al., 2016), and carbohydrate accumulation in potato (Turakainen et al., 2004). Many nanoparticles were effective when used with micronutrients, raising the potential for enhanced plant growth with nutritional benefits. Se plays a role in the physiology and metabolism of plants, and increasing the Se concentration to a certain degreewill increase the content of Se in various products, resulting in increased plant yield by protecting chl (Ramos et al., 2010). Se increases the possibility of leaf production in plants by increasing antioxidant activity, possibly due to increased starch accumulation in chloroplasts (Malorgio et al., 2009) or the protection of cellular proteins (Xue et al., 2001).

sections.heading: 4.2. Effect of nano-selenium and selenium foliar spray on leaf mineral content
sections.text:
In pomegranate, foliar application of Se and N-Se increased leaf nutrient (N, P, K and Ca) content compared with control trees, except for Mn in the first year (Table 3) and improved other fruit-related
m L. cv. Malase Saveh) leaf mineral concentration (macro-elements) in 2016 and 2017.
parameters (Tables 4 and 5). Foliar application of Ca improved thenutrient status of kiwifruit (Actinidia deliciosa) (Koutinas et al., 2010). An increase in leaf N increases net photosynthesis rate, but onlywhen carbon fixation is maximum (Meziane and Shipley, 2001). The application of silicon (Si) to soil improvedN, P, K and Si (but notMg) content of sapota (Manilkara zapota) fruit (Lalithya et al., 2014) or leaf N, P, K andMg content in Valencia orange when combined with boron, K and/or Se (Ibrahim and Al-Wasfy, 2014). Kostopoulou et al. (2015a) found that the application of Se in irrigation water during water stress reduced
Mg content in the aerial parts of yellow sweet clover (Melilotus officinalis) when applied at 3 mg/L but increased it when applied at 1 mg/L, while the content of Fe, Zn and Mn decreased at both concentrations. In pomegranate, the application of Se or N-Se did not affect Mn content in leaves in the first year while Mn content increased significantly in response to Se (1 and 2 μM) and N-Se (2 μM) (Table 3). Foliar application of Se is an efficient way to enrich plants with this element (Kápolna et al., 2009). Foliar application with Se significantly improved the uptake of some nutrients (Se, Fe and Na) and yield of wheat by

Malase Saveh) using thedata obtained in 2016 (left) and 2017 (right). (A) PCA loading plot of PC1 and PC2of the examined variable traits; circles indicate themost correlated variables. (B) PCA individual plot of Se and Se-NP treatments on pomegranate trees. The tested variables included: leaf area, LA; chlorophyll content, Total Chl; number of fruits/tree, No. fruit; nitrogen, N; phosphorus, P; potassium, K; calcium, Ca; iron, Fe; manganese, Mn; zinc, Zn; peel thickness, P. Thick; fruit cracking, Fruit C; fruit weight, Fruit W; fruit length, Fruit L; fruit diameter, Fruit D; weight of 100 arils, W Aril; juice content, Juice C; total soluble solids, TSS; titratable acidity, TA;maturity index, MI; total sugars, TS; total phenolic compounds, TPC; antioxidant activity, DPPH; total anthocyanins, TAC; dimension 1, Dim1; dimension 2, Dim2; contribution, Contrib; squared cosine, Cos2.
maintaining turgor (Nawaz et al., 2015), and can change the concentration of micro- and macroelements depending on the type of plant and tissue studied (Kostopoulou et al., 2015b). In our study, the application of Se to the nutrient solution resulted, when compared with control trees, in a proportional increase in Se concentration in the leaves. It seems that physiological processes and biochemical activities, including enzyme activation, control the uptake of elements that defines the nutritional status of plants. However, interactions between Se and other elements are also well-reported in the literature. For example,
Yao et al. (2009) noted that exogenously applied Se significantly enhanced the uptake of Fe, K and Zn in wheat (Triticum aestivum).

sections.heading: 4.3. Effect of nano-selenium and selenium foliar spray on biochemical properties
sections.text:
Se and N-Se at 2 μM significantly increased total soluble sugar content in pomegranate fruits in both years (Table 4) which in turn increased TSS content (Table 6). A similar trend was observed for sapota
(Lalithya et al., 2014) and potato (Ibrahim and Ibrahim, 2016). An increase in total soluble sugars after the application of Se is related to an increase in the activity of fructose 1,6-bisphosphatase, a key enzyme in carbohydrate metabolism, as was observed for alfalfa (Medicago sativa) (Owusu-Sckyere et al., 2013). The foliar application of Zn and B increased total sugar content of mandarin (Citrus reticulata) fruits (Babu and Yadav, 2005). Furthermore, this suggests that Se might also exert a positive influence on the fruit taste.
Badawy et al. (2017) observed that Se applied at 2 mg/L, but only when Bo was also applied at 2 mg/L, improved total soluble phenol and protein content in canola (Brassica napus). Se is a cofactor in the reduction of peroxides, which can damage cells and tissues, and can act as an antioxidant (Puccinelli et al., 2017). In pomegranate, Se (and to some extentN-Se) improved anthocyanin (aflavonoid) content (Table 4). Anthocyanins serve as antioxidants and offer protection against abiotic stresses in plants (Agati et al., 2012) by protecting chl from photooxidation (Hatier and Gould, 2008). Se as selenite or selenite below the toxicity threshold (b15 μM) could biofortify lettuce by accumulating more S (Hawrylak-Nowak, 2013) as a result of the incorporation of Se as selenoproteins (Lu and Holmgren, 2009). Wheat seedlings soaked in Se enhanced anthocyanin and sugar content under low temperature stress (Akladious, 2012). An increase in anthocyanin content increases the ability to scavenge free radicals and inhibit membrane lipid peroxidation (Chu et al., 2010). These results suggest that the application of Se can improve antioxidant defense, improving plant growth in arid and semiarid regions (Hartikainen et al., 2000; Cartes et al., 2010; Hasanuzzaman et al., 2010) due to its ability to stimulate the production of anthocyanins, thereby enhancing the antioxidative capacity of tea (Camelia sinensis) leaves (Xu et al., 2003), rice (Oryza sativa) extracts (Xu et al., 2004). N-Se can serve as an antioxidant with a reduced risk of Se toxicity (Zhang et al., 2007).
Total phenolic compound content is one of the most important nutritional value parameters in pomegranate fruits (Tehranifar et al., 2010a, 2010b), found at 300–1000 mg/100 g fresh weigh in Iranian pomegranate varieties (Davarpanah et al., 2016). Xu et al. (2003, 2004), Motomura et al. (2008), Bystrická et al. (2015) and Badawy et al. (2017) found, for several plant species, that Se fertilizer significantly enhanced total polyphenol content, similar to our findingwith the foliar application of Se and N-Se in pomegranate (Table 4), thereby enhancing abiotic stress tolerance by enhancing antioxidative capacity (Ríos et al., 2009). Se upregulated the phenylpropanoid biosynthetic pathway leading to the accumulation of metabolites (flavonoids and polyphenols) that play a key role in determining the organoleptic features and the antioxidant capacity of fruits (Mimmo et al., 2017). Despite this evidence, their metabolomic analysis did not show a statistically significant accumulation of Se-containing metabolites in pomegranate.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusion
sections.text:
Our results show that the use of Se or N-Se as a foliar spray at full bloom and again one month later significantly increase quality and organoleptic properties of fruit, and the nutritional and biochemical status of leaves. Se and N-Se also controlled fruit cracking. Additional studies are needed to further optimize the concentration and timing of Se and N-Se applications to a wider range of cultivars while the physiological mechanism that underlies the beneficial role of N-Se needs to be further explored.
Conflicts of interest
The authors declare that they have no competing interests.
Author statement
S.M.Z and M.S.H. performed the experiments and contributed experimental data; S.M.Z and M.S.H designed the experiments and
conducted the research; S.M.Z. and M.S.H. performed the analyses; J.A.T.S. critically assessed the experimental protocol and assisted with data analyses; S.M.Z. and N.D.H.M. and J.A.T.S. wrote the manuscript.

sections.text: The authors are grateful to the University of Maragheh for providing financial support and Hamedan Science and Technology Park for providing laboratory equipment.

referenceMentions.context: ; Punicaceae) is a fruit-bearing deciduous shrub or small tree that originated from Iran and iswell adapted to a Mediterranean climate, and is thus grown extensively around the globe, but primarily in Spain, India, Egypt, Afghanistan and the USA (Davarpanah et al., 2018).
Pomegranate is mainly consumed as a fresh fruit, but it is also used in jams, juices, wines, vinegars and jellies (Gumienna et al., 2016).

This fruit is widely adapted to a wide range of climates and water conditions and is able to tolerate abiotic stresses (Rodríguez Hernández et al., 2012; Teixeira da Silva et al., 2013; Bugueño et al., 2016).
Pomegranate growth and yield are affected by climate, soil conditions, cultivar, insect management, tree nutrition management, and irrigation (Obaid and Al-Hadethi, 2013).

In plants, Se is needed for antioxidant defense since it induces the expression of sulfur assimilation genes (Djanaguiraman et al., 2010; Hasanuzzaman et al., 2014) and is an integral part of the enzyme glutathione peroxidase (Peng et al.

In plants, Se is needed for antioxidant defense since it induces the expression of sulfur assimilation genes (Djanaguiraman et al., 2010; Hasanuzzaman et al., 2014) and is an integral part of the enzyme glutathione peroxidase (Peng et al.
, 2014) and is an integral part of the enzyme glutathione peroxidase (Peng et al., 2007; Hajiboland et al., 2015).
, 2014) and is an integral part of the enzyme glutathione peroxidase (Peng et al., 2007; Hajiboland et al., 2015).
Supplementationwith Se can enhance glutathione peroxidase (GPx) and the activity of other Se-based proteins (Oraghi-Ardebili et al., 2015).
Hawrylak-Nowak, 2009), heavy metals (Cartes et al., 2010; MroczekZdyrska andWójcik, 2012), and drought (Yao et al.
, 2010; MroczekZdyrska andWójcik, 2012), and drought (Yao et al., 2009).
It exerts beneficial effects on plant growth and stress tolerance by enhancing their antioxidative capacity (Ríos et al., 2009).

Even though several studies has been conducted on the effect of Se on some plants, including positive aspects (Haghighi et al., 2014; Bystrická et al., 2015), it has still not yet clear if Se is an essential element for plants.

Even though several studies has been conducted on the effect of Se on some plants, including positive aspects (Haghighi et al., 2014; Bystrická et al., 2015), it has still not yet clear if Se is an essential element for plants.
Despite this, the positive effect of Se at 2–10 μM on growth or yield-related parameters has been shown in orange tree (Ibrahim and Al-Wasfy, 2014), sorghum (Djanaguiraman et al.

Despite this, the positive effect of Se at 2–10 μM on growth or yield-related parameters has been shown in orange tree (Ibrahim and Al-Wasfy, 2014), sorghum (Djanaguiraman et al., 2010), tomato (Haghighi et al.
, 2010), tomato (Haghighi et al., 2014; Bystrická et al., 2015) and some other plants (Cartes et al.
, 2010), tomato (Haghighi et al., 2014; Bystrická et al., 2015) and some other plants (Cartes et al.
In several cases, Se enhanced yield- and growth-related characters, but the improvement was dependent on concentration (Djanaguiraman et al., 2010; Haghighi et al., 2014; Ibrahim and Al-Wasfy, 2014).
In several cases, Se enhanced yield- and growth-related characters, but the improvement was dependent on concentration (Djanaguiraman et al., 2010; Haghighi et al., 2014; Ibrahim and Al-Wasfy, 2014).
In several cases, Se enhanced yield- and growth-related characters, but the improvement was dependent on concentration (Djanaguiraman et al., 2010; Haghighi et al., 2014; Ibrahim and Al-Wasfy, 2014).
Most agricultural crops have a much lower ability to adapt to Se (b50 mg Se/kg) but some plants with a high sulfur (S) content have a high Se concentration (Puccinelli et al., 2017).
Se may prevent oxidative damage by inducing a higher expression of S-assimilation genes (Djanaguiraman et al., 2010) or the production of polyphenols (Bystrická et al.
, 2010) or the production of polyphenols (Bystrická et al., 2015).

Some crop production areas around theworld are deficient in Se, so different forms of this element have been used, either as a foliar or soil application, or in seed priming, to increase the growth, quality or edible parts of crops (Djanaguiraman et al., 2010; Haghighi et al., 2014; Ibrahim and Al-Wasfy, 2014).

Some crop production areas around theworld are deficient in Se, so different forms of this element have been used, either as a foliar or soil application, or in seed priming, to increase the growth, quality or edible parts of crops (Djanaguiraman et al., 2010; Haghighi et al., 2014; Ibrahim and Al-Wasfy, 2014).

Some crop production areas around theworld are deficient in Se, so different forms of this element have been used, either as a foliar or soil application, or in seed priming, to increase the growth, quality or edible parts of crops (Djanaguiraman et al., 2010; Haghighi et al., 2014; Ibrahim and Al-Wasfy, 2014).
Nanoparticles are atomic or molecular aggregates with a size ranging from 1 to 100 nm than can affect the physicochemical properties of a substance relative to its bulk form (Pérez-de-Luque, 2017).

Nanoparticles such as nano-Se (N-Se), which is soluble and highly stable (Sharma et al., 2014), has attracted widespread attention because of its low toxicity and high bioavailability (Abdulsalam et al.
, 2014), has attracted widespread attention because of its low toxicity and high bioavailability (Abdulsalam et al., 2018).
The size of nanoparticles plays an important role in their biological activity, especially in the range of 5–200 nm, so N-Se can scavenge free radicals in a size-dependent manner (Peng et al., 2007).
N-Se has excellent bioavailability, high biological activity, and low toxicity in plants (Zhang et al., 2001).
1,000,000 tons, respectively (FAOSTAT, 2018), accounting for 25% of global pomegranate-related exports (Salehi et al., 2016).

Fruit cracking is a major problem in pomegranate fruit production in many agricultural areas in Iran and causes financial losses to growers each year amounting to losses exceeding more than 35% of pomegranate production (Mirzaee et al., 2017).

Leaves were sampled from the middle part of fruit-bearing branches (a total of 85 leaves were sampled from three branches within each tree canopy) on September 1 in the first year and on August 25 in the second year (approximately 90 days after full bloom) (Davarpanah et al., 2016).
N content was determined using the Kjeldhal method (Eaton et al., 1995).
Se concentration was then determined by ICP-OES (Mimmo et al., 2017).
Chlorophyll (chl) content was recorded using exactly the same leaves from the same plants, using a SPAD-502 chl meter (Konica-Minolta, Tokyo, Japan) (Mielke et al., 2010).
Total antioxidant activity in juice was assessed using the 2,2diphenyl-1-picrylhydrazyl (DPPH) assay (Dokhanieh et al., 2013).
Gallic acid was used as the standard (Mirdehghan and Rahimi, 2016).
Total soluble sugar in juice was determined by the anthrone reagent method (Dubois et al., 1951).
Some researchers did not observe any positive effect of Se on chl content in plants such as potato (Solanum tuberosum) (Germ et al., 2007) and sorghum (Sorghum bicolor) (Djanaguiraman et al.
, 2007) and sorghum (Sorghum bicolor) (Djanaguiraman et al., 2010).
In contrast, chl content was significantly increased in potato when Se was applied at 10 mg/L (Germ et al., 2007), 50 mg/L in soybean (Glycine max) (Djanaguiraman et al.
, 2007), 50 mg/L in soybean (Glycine max) (Djanaguiraman et al., 2005), 5 μM in tomato (Solanum lycopersicum) (Haghighi et al.

, 2005), 5 μM in tomato (Solanum lycopersicum) (Haghighi et al., 2014), 50 mg/L in citrus (Ibrahim and Al-Wasfy, 2014), and 10 μM in potato (Ibrahim and Ibrahim, 2016), or by the application of 1 μMN-Se in tomato (Haghighi et al.
, 2014), 50 mg/L in citrus (Ibrahim and Al-Wasfy, 2014), and 10 μM in potato (Ibrahim and Ibrahim, 2016), or by the application of 1 μMN-Se in tomato (Haghighi et al.
, 2014), 50 mg/L in citrus (Ibrahim and Al-Wasfy, 2014), and 10 μM in potato (Ibrahim and Ibrahim, 2016), or by the application of 1 μMN-Se in tomato (Haghighi et al.

, 2014), 50 mg/L in citrus (Ibrahim and Al-Wasfy, 2014), and 10 μM in potato (Ibrahim and Ibrahim, 2016), or by the application of 1 μMN-Se in tomato (Haghighi et al., 2014) or 400 mg/L in cluster bean (Ragavan et al.
, 2014) or 400 mg/L in cluster bean (Ragavan et al., 2017).
These different results may be due to differences in crop species, experimental conditions, or the plants' ability to biofortify Se (Haghighi et al., 2014).

The optimal concentration of Se may play an important role in increasing leaf pigments by enhancing the capacity of antioxidants and delaying the senescence of leaf tissues while an increase in chl content may be attributed to the ability of Se to protect chloroplast enzymes, affect the oxidation reduction status of leaves, and thus increase the biosynthesis of photosynthetic pigments (Zhong and Cheng, 2017).
Seinduced plant growth was due to an increase in starch accumulation in chloroplasts (Turakainen et al., 2004).

Pomegranate yield, expressed as theweight of fruits/tree and fruit-related parameters (length, weight and diameter), improved significantly in response to Se, even more so with N-Se, relative to the control (Tables 2 and 5), as was also found in jujube (Ziziphus jujuba) trees by applying a foliar Se spray (Jing et al., 2017).
Yield is related to physiological responses such as photosynthesis that may enhance chl content (Sid'ko et al., 2017).
The use of Se also increased yield in citrus (Ibrahim and Ibrahim, 2016), biomass and yield in garlic (Allium sativum) (Põldma et al.

The use of Se also increased yield in citrus (Ibrahim and Ibrahim, 2016), biomass and yield in garlic (Allium sativum) (Põldma et al., 2013; Cheng et al., 2016), and carbohydrate accumulation in potato (Turakainen et al.

The use of Se also increased yield in citrus (Ibrahim and Ibrahim, 2016), biomass and yield in garlic (Allium sativum) (Põldma et al., 2013; Cheng et al., 2016), and carbohydrate accumulation in potato (Turakainen et al.
, 2016), and carbohydrate accumulation in potato (Turakainen et al., 2004).

Se plays a role in the physiology and metabolism of plants, and increasing the Se concentration to a certain degreewill increase the content of Se in various products, resulting in increased plant yield by protecting chl (Ramos et al., 2010).

Se increases the possibility of leaf production in plants by increasing antioxidant activity, possibly due to increased starch accumulation in chloroplasts (Malorgio et al., 2009) or the protection of cellular proteins (Xue et al.
, 2009) or the protection of cellular proteins (Xue et al., 2001).
Foliar application of Ca improved thenutrient status of kiwifruit (Actinidia deliciosa) (Koutinas et al., 2010).
An increase in leaf N increases net photosynthesis rate, but onlywhen carbon fixation is maximum (Meziane and Shipley, 2001).

The application of silicon (Si) to soil improvedN, P, K and Si (but notMg) content of sapota (Manilkara zapota) fruit (Lalithya et al., 2014) or leaf N, P, K andMg content in Valencia orange when combined with boron, K and/or Se (Ibrahim and Al-Wasfy, 2014).
, 2014) or leaf N, P, K andMg content in Valencia orange when combined with boron, K and/or Se (Ibrahim and Al-Wasfy, 2014).
Foliar application of Se is an efficient way to enrich plants with this element (Kápolna et al., 2009).
maintaining turgor (Nawaz et al., 2015), and can change the concentration of micro- and macroelements depending on the type of plant and tissue studied (Kostopoulou et al.
(Lalithya et al., 2014) and potato (Ibrahim and Ibrahim, 2016).

An increase in total soluble sugars after the application of Se is related to an increase in the activity of fructose 1,6-bisphosphatase, a key enzyme in carbohydrate metabolism, as was observed for alfalfa (Medicago sativa) (Owusu-Sckyere et al., 2013).
The foliar application of Zn and B increased total sugar content of mandarin (Citrus reticulata) fruits (Babu and Yadav, 2005).
Se is a cofactor in the reduction of peroxides, which can damage cells and tissues, and can act as an antioxidant (Puccinelli et al., 2017).
Anthocyanins serve as antioxidants and offer protection against abiotic stresses in plants (Agati et al., 2012) by protecting chl from photooxidation (Hatier and Gould, 2008).
, 2012) by protecting chl from photooxidation (Hatier and Gould, 2008).

Se as selenite or selenite below the toxicity threshold (b15 μM) could biofortify lettuce by accumulating more S (Hawrylak-Nowak, 2013) as a result of the incorporation of Se as selenoproteins (Lu and Holmgren, 2009).
Wheat seedlings soaked in Se enhanced anthocyanin and sugar content under low temperature stress (Akladious, 2012).
An increase in anthocyanin content increases the ability to scavenge free radicals and inhibit membrane lipid peroxidation (Chu et al., 2010).

These results suggest that the application of Se can improve antioxidant defense, improving plant growth in arid and semiarid regions (Hartikainen et al., 2000; Cartes et al., 2010; Hasanuzzaman et al., 2010) due to its ability to stimulate the production of anthocyanins, thereby enhancing the antioxidative capacity of tea (Camelia sinensis) leaves (Xu et al.

, 2010) due to its ability to stimulate the production of anthocyanins, thereby enhancing the antioxidative capacity of tea (Camelia sinensis) leaves (Xu et al., 2003), rice (Oryza sativa) extracts (Xu et al.
, 2003), rice (Oryza sativa) extracts (Xu et al., 2004).
N-Se can serve as an antioxidant with a reduced risk of Se toxicity (Zhang et al., 2007).
, 2010a, 2010b), found at 300–1000 mg/100 g fresh weigh in Iranian pomegranate varieties (Davarpanah et al., 2016).

(2017) found, for several plant species, that Se fertilizer significantly enhanced total polyphenol content, similar to our findingwith the foliar application of Se and N-Se in pomegranate (Table 4), thereby enhancing abiotic stress tolerance by enhancing antioxidative capacity (Ríos et al., 2009).

Se upregulated the phenylpropanoid biosynthetic pathway leading to the accumulation of metabolites (flavonoids and polyphenols) that play a key role in determining the organoleptic features and the antioxidant capacity of fruits (Mimmo et al., 2017).
